nexttext: starting from a product wave function

with the operators $\{S_j^{\dagger},S_j,S_j^0,j=1 \dots L\}$ satisfying the commutation relations of a set of spin-$1/2$ $su(2)$ algebras and the set of $\{v_{\alpha}^2,\alpha=1 \dots L\}$ to be determined. This wavefunction does not contain a definite particle number due to the presence of the constant factor $\lambda/v_{\alpha}^2$ in the generalized creation operator $S^{\dagger}(v_{\alpha})$. Because of the commutativity, all conserved operators share a common set of eigenstates, and we will derive the conditions for the product state (\ref{pm:eigenstate}) to be an eigenstate of $R_{\mathbf{k}}$. The action on the wave function can be determined through a Richardson-Gaudin commutator scheme as
prevtext: starting from a product wave function
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E2.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle{|{\psi}\rangle}=\prod_{\alpha=1}^{L}S^{\dagger}(v_{\alpha}){|{%
\downarrow\cdots\downarrow}\rangle},\qquad S^{\dagger}(v_{\alpha})=-\frac{%
\lambda}{v_{\alpha}^{2}}+G\sum_{j=1}^{L}\frac{\epsilon_{j}}{\epsilon_{j}^{2}-v%
_{\alpha}^{2}}S^{\dagger}_{j}," display="inline"><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mi>ψ</mi><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∏</mo><mrow><mi>α</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi>L</mi></munderover></mstyle><msup><mi>S</mi><mo>†</mo></msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>v</mi><mi>α</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mo>↓</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">⋯</mi><mo>↓</mo><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo><mo rspace="22.5pt">,</mo><mi>S</mi><msup><mi/><mo>†</mo></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>v</mi><mi>α</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mi>λ</mi><msubsup><mi>v</mi><mi>α</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup></mfrac></mstyle><mo>+</mo><mi>G</mi><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo></mstyle><msub><mi/><mrow><mi>j</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><msup><mi/><mi>L</mi></msup><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><msub><mi>ϵ</mi><mi>j</mi></msub><mrow><msubsup><mi>ϵ</mi><mi>j</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mo>-</mo><msubsup><mi>v</mi><mi>α</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup></mrow></mfrac></mstyle><mi>S</mi><msup><mi/><mo>†</mo></msup><msub><mi/><mi>j</mi></msub><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: The necessary commutation relations are given by
prevtext: with the operators $\{S_j^{\dagger},S_j,S_j^0,j=1 \dots L\}$ satisfying the commutation relations of a set of spin-$1/2$ $su(2)$ algebras and the set of $\{v_{\alpha}^2,\alpha=1 \dots L\}$ to be determined. This wavefunction does not contain a definite particle number due to the presence of the constant factor $\lambda/v_{\alpha}^2$ in the generalized creation operator $S^{\dagger}(v_{\alpha})$. Because of the commutativity, all conserved operators share a common set of eigenstates, and we will derive the conditions for the product state (\ref{pm:eigenstate}) to be an eigenstate of $R_{\mathbf{k}}$. The action on the wave function can be determined through a Richardson-Gaudin commutator scheme as
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex1.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle R_{\mathbf{k}}\prod_{\alpha=1}^{L}S^{\dagger}(v_{\alpha}){|{%
\downarrow\cdots\downarrow}\rangle}=" display="inline"><mrow><msub><mi>R</mi><mi>𝐤</mi></msub><mstyle displaystyle="true"><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∏</mo><mrow><mi>α</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi>L</mi></munderover></mstyle><msup><mi>S</mi><mo>†</mo></msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>v</mi><mi>α</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mo>↓</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">⋯</mi><mo>↓</mo><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo><mo>=</mo></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex1.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle\sum_{\alpha=1}^{L}\sum_{\beta=\alpha+1}^{L}\left(\prod_{\gamma%
\neq\alpha,\beta}^{L}S^{\dagger}(v_{\gamma})\right)[[R_{\mathbf{k}},{S^{%
\dagger}(v_{{\alpha}})}],{S^{\dagger}(v_{{\beta}})}]{|{\downarrow\cdots%
\downarrow}\rangle}" display="inline"><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>α</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi>L</mi></munderover></mstyle><mstyle displaystyle="true"><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>β</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi>α</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mrow><mi>L</mi></munderover></mstyle><mrow><mo>(</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∏</mo><mrow><mi>γ</mi><mo>≠</mo><mrow><mi>α</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>β</mi></mrow></mrow><mi>L</mi></munderover></mstyle><msup><mi>S</mi><mo>†</mo></msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>v</mi><mi>γ</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msub><mi>R</mi><mi>𝐤</mi></msub><mo>,</mo><msup><mi>S</mi><mo>†</mo></msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>v</mi><mi>α</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mo>,</mo><msup><mi>S</mi><mo>†</mo></msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>v</mi><mi>β</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mo>↓</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">⋯</mi><mo>↓</mo><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E3.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle+\sum_{\alpha=1}^{L}\left(\prod_{\beta\neq\alpha}^{L}S^{\dagger}(%
v_{\beta})\right)[R_{\mathbf{k}},{S^{\dagger}(v_{{\alpha}})}]{|{\downarrow%
\cdots\downarrow}\rangle}+\left(\prod_{\alpha=1}^{L}S^{\dagger}(v_{\alpha})%
\right)R_{\mathbf{k}}{|{\downarrow\cdots\downarrow}\rangle}." display="inline"><mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>α</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi>L</mi></munderover></mstyle><mrow><mo>(</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∏</mo><mrow><mi>β</mi><mo>≠</mo><mi>α</mi></mrow><mi>L</mi></munderover></mstyle><msup><mi>S</mi><mo>†</mo></msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>v</mi><mi>β</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msub><mi>R</mi><mi>𝐤</mi></msub><mo>,</mo><msup><mi>S</mi><mo>†</mo></msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>v</mi><mi>α</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mo>↓</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">⋯</mi><mo>↓</mo><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∏</mo><mrow><mi>α</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi>L</mi></munderover></mstyle><msup><mi>S</mi><mo>†</mo></msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>v</mi><mi>α</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><msub><mi>R</mi><mi>𝐤</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mo>↓</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">⋯</mi><mo>↓</mo><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: In order to be an eigenstate, the two unwanted (non-diagonal) terms should cancel. It can be shown that the contributions from different excitation sectors cancel termwise provided the variables $\{v_{\alpha}^2,\alpha=1 \dots L\}$ satisfy a set of Bethe ansatz equations. We first check the contribution from both terms to the state $S^{\dagger}_k{|{\downarrow \cdots \downarrow}\rangle}$ containing one excitation, which vanishes provided the set of equations

nexttext: are satisfied. These can be brought in the previously-obtained form \cite{lukyanenko_integrable_2015}
prevtext: In order to be an eigenstate, the two unwanted (non-diagonal) terms should cancel. It can be shown that the contributions from different excitation sectors cancel termwise provided the variables $\{v_{\alpha}^2,\alpha=1 \dots L\}$ satisfy a set of Bethe ansatz equations. We first check the contribution from both terms to the state $S^{\dagger}_k{|{\downarrow \cdots \downarrow}\rangle}$ containing one excitation, which vanishes provided the set of equations

\alpha}^{2}}\left[(1+G)-G\sum_{j=1}^{L}\frac{\epsilon_{j}^{2}}{\epsilon_{j}^{2%
}-v_{\alpha}^{2}}+2G\sum_{\beta\neq\alpha}^{L}\frac{v_{\beta}^{2}}{v_{\beta}^{%
2}-v_{\alpha}^{2}}\right]=\frac{\gamma\lambda}{G}," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>α</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi>L</mi></munderover><mrow><mfrac><mrow><msubsup><mi>ϵ</mi><mi>k</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>v</mi><mi>α</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup></mrow><mrow><msubsup><mi>ϵ</mi><mi>k</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mo>-</mo><msubsup><mi>v</mi><mi>α</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup></mrow></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mi>G</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>G</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>j</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi>L</mi></munderover><mfrac><msubsup><mi>ϵ</mi><mi>j</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mrow><msubsup><mi>ϵ</mi><mi>j</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mo>-</mo><msubsup><mi>v</mi><mi>α</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>G</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>β</mi><mo>≠</mo><mi>α</mi></mrow><mi>L</mi></munderover><mfrac><msubsup><mi>v</mi><mi>β</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mrow><msubsup><mi>v</mi><mi>β</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mo>-</mo><msubsup><mi>v</mi><mi>α</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>γ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>λ</mi></mrow><mi>G</mi></mfrac></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: by interpreting (\ref{pm:matvecmult}) as a matrix-vector multiplication and multiplying with the well-known inverse of a Cauchy matrix. This requirement only cancels one contribution from both unwanted terms, all other contributions should also cancel exactly in order for (\ref{pm:eigenstate}) to be an eigenstate. The coefficient in front of a state with $N+1$ excitations where the set of spins labelled $\{i_1, \dots, i_N,k\}$ are flipped up is proportional to
prevtext: are satisfied. These can be brought in the previously-obtained form \cite{lukyanenko_integrable_2015}
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E7.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="(1+G)-G\sum_{j=1}^{L}\frac{\epsilon_{j}^{2}}{\epsilon_{j}^{2}-v_{\alpha}^{2}}+%
2G\sum_{\beta\neq\alpha}^{L}\frac{v_{\beta}^{2}}{v_{\beta}^{2}-v_{\alpha}^{2}}%
=\frac{\gamma\lambda}{G}\frac{\prod_{j=1}^{L}(v_{\alpha}^{-2}-\epsilon_{j}^{-2%
})}{\prod_{\beta\neq\alpha}^{L}(v_{\alpha}^{-2}-v_{\beta}^{-2})}," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mi>G</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>G</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>j</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi>L</mi></munderover><mfrac><msubsup><mi>ϵ</mi><mi>j</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mrow><msubsup><mi>ϵ</mi><mi>j</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mo>-</mo><msubsup><mi>v</mi><mi>α</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>G</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>β</mi><mo>≠</mo><mi>α</mi></mrow><mi>L</mi></munderover><mfrac><msubsup><mi>v</mi><mi>β</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mrow><msubsup><mi>v</mi><mi>β</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mo>-</mo><msubsup><mi>v</mi><mi>α</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>γ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>λ</mi></mrow><mi>G</mi></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mfrac><mrow><msubsup><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∏</mo><mrow><mi>j</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi>L</mi></msubsup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msubsup><mi>v</mi><mi>α</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msubsup><mo>-</mo><msubsup><mi>ϵ</mi><mi>j</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msubsup></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><msubsup><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∏</mo><mrow><mi>β</mi><mo>≠</mo><mi>α</mi></mrow><mi>L</mi></msubsup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msubsup><mi>v</mi><mi>α</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msubsup><mo>-</mo><msubsup><mi>v</mi><mi>β</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msubsup></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext: by interpreting (\ref{pm:matvecmult}) as a matrix-vector multiplication and multiplying with the well-known inverse of a Cauchy matrix. This requirement only cancels one contribution from both unwanted terms, all other contributions should also cancel exactly in order for (\ref{pm:eigenstate}) to be an eigenstate. The coefficient in front of a state with $N+1$ excitations where the set of spins labelled $\{i_1, \dots, i_N,k\}$ are flipped up is proportional to
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E8.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle C^{N}_{\{i_{1},\dots,i_{N},k\}}=\sum_{\alpha=1}^{L}\frac{F_{%
\alpha}}{\epsilon_{k}^{-2}-v_{\alpha}^{-2}}" display="inline"><mrow><msubsup><mi>C</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">{</mo><msub><mi>i</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">…</mi><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>i</mi><mi>N</mi></msub><mo>,</mo><mi>k</mi><mo stretchy="false">}</mo></mrow><mi>N</mi></msubsup><mo>=</mo><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>α</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi>L</mi></munderover></mstyle><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><msub><mi>F</mi><mi>α</mi></msub><mrow><msubsup><mi>ϵ</mi><mi>k</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msubsup><mo>-</mo><msubsup><mi>v</mi><mi>α</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msubsup></mrow></mfrac></mstyle></mrow></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E8.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle\left[\sum_{\hat{A}\in S^{N}_{\hat{\alpha}}}\frac{1}{\prod_{j=1}^%
{N}(\epsilon_{i_{j}}^{-2}-\hat{\nu}^{-2}_{j})}\right]+\frac{\gamma\lambda}{G}%
\left[\sum_{A\in S^{N}}\frac{1}{\prod_{j=1}^{N}(\epsilon_{i_{j}}^{-2}-\nu_{j}^%
{-2})}\right]," display="inline"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mover accent="true"><mi>A</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mo>∈</mo><msubsup><mi>S</mi><mover accent="true"><mi>α</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mi>N</mi></msubsup></mrow></munder></mstyle><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><msubsup><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∏</mo><mrow><mi>j</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi>N</mi></msubsup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msubsup><mi>ϵ</mi><msub><mi>i</mi><mi>j</mi></msub><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msubsup><mo>-</mo><msubsup><mover accent="true"><mi>ν</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mi>j</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msubsup></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mfrac></mstyle></mrow><mo>]</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><mi>γ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>λ</mi></mrow><mi>G</mi></mfrac></mstyle><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>A</mi><mo>∈</mo><msup><mi>S</mi><mi>N</mi></msup></mrow></munder></mstyle><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><msubsup><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∏</mo><mrow><mi>j</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi>N</mi></msubsup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msubsup><mi>ϵ</mi><msub><mi>i</mi><mi>j</mi></msub><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msubsup><mo>-</mo><msubsup><mi>ν</mi><mi>j</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msubsup></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mfrac></mstyle></mrow><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
and $S^N_{\hat{\alpha}}$ the set of all $N$-tuples built out of $N$ non-repeated elements $\{v_1, \dots v_{\alpha-1},v_{\alpha+1}, \dots, v_L\}$ and $S_N$ the set of all $N$-tuples built from $\{v_1, \dots, v_L\}$. The elements of these sets are denoted $\hat{A}_j=\{\hat{\nu}_1, \dots, \hat{\nu}_{N}\}$ and $A_j=\{\nu_1, \dots, \nu_N\}$. A highly similar expression was obtained in the study of the DJCG models, where it was proven that these expressions vanish provided the BAE equations are satisfied \cite{tschirhart_algebraic_2014}. The full proof that (\ref{pm:unwantedterms}) equals zero is completely analogous and does not depend on the explicit form of the BAE, rather on the structure from (\ref{pm:matvecmult}).
